issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Adding a queue to the capacity scheduler while the RM is running and then running a job in the queue added results in very strange behavior.  The cluster Total Memory can either decrease or increase.  We had a cluster where total memory decreased to almost 1/6th the capacity. Running on a small test cluster resulted in the capacity going up by simply adding a queue and running wordcount.  

Looking at the RM logs, used memory can go negative but other logs show the number positive:


2012-10-21 22:56:44,796 [ResourceManager Event Processor] INFO org.apache.hadoop.yarn.server.resourcemanager.scheduler.capacity.ParentQueue: assignedContainer queue=root usedCapacity=0.0375 absoluteUsedCapacity=0.0375 used=memory: 7680 cluster=memory: 204800

2012-10-21 22:56:45,831 [ResourceManager Event Processor] INFO org.apache.hadoop.yarn.server.resourcemanager.scheduler.capacity.ParentQueue: completedContainer queue=root usedCapacity=-0.0225 absoluteUsedCapacity=-0.0225 used=memory: -4608 cluster=memory: 204800
fields.summary: CapacityScheduler - adding a queue while the RM is running has wacky results

comments.body: I met the same issue in hadoop 2.0.1

I believe the issue here is that the parent of the new queue is not getting set appropriately.  When re-initializing it creates an entire new root queue from the configs and then it moves any new queues over to the original root.  It doesn't appear to set the parent from the new root back to the original root when it moves it over.
Good catch Tom, here is a simple fix. I'll test some more and add some unit tests.

Thanks Arun.  Here is an updated patch fixing the findbugs warning. Looks good to me other then adding some unit tests like you said.

I manually tested with both adding some multi-level queues and a single level queue and am no longer seeing the issue.

well I guess I didn't fix it.  The issue is we are inconsistent about synchronizing around the parent usage.
The LeafQueue has a setParentQueue that is unused and can be removed now.
Fixed findbugs and added a unit test.
